turn.0: ELI5: If at first there was nothing, how was there anything to cause The Big Bang?
turn.1: Singularities are so weird, as they’re essentially just points where every concept and “law” we know of stop applying. Every advance we have made in understanding let’s us go a little bit deeper; but it always breaks down again. I don’t expect we can ever know enough not to be left with some question or paradox.  I still can’t properly wrap my head around the speed of light when “riding the photon”. It took 13billion years for the light to get to us from the Big Bang. It spent 13billion years moving. But, when you move at light speed, time changes. So from the perspective of the photon... it’s instant? No time elapses from its perspective? It is everywhere everytime all at once? Brain melting.
turn.2: I’m somehow dumber than I was an hour ago. So, if I’m understanding your point, it’s possible there is no origin in the construct of what we understand as an origin? Meaning, I understand a baby came from it’s mother, etc., but there may not be that sort of concept with the origin of this...everything? Am I ball-parking your comment’s intent?
turn.3: Kind of. There is an origin - we know it was about 13billion years ago, and I believe we have some models for the Big Bang that work down to a few seconds after it started... but, ultimately, if there wasn’t a “before” the start, that means there can’t have been *a cause* of the Big Bang as the very concept of “causing something” in itself relies on there being *a before* state.  It’s likely we will be able to get closer and closer to “the start”, but much like when we travel half the distance from A to B, then half again... etc... we approach B, but never get to it.
turn.4: That’s an excellent point. Halving the distance means you’ll never get there. The why, how, and what has always thrown me for a loop with this question. I wish there was some cosmic repository with all the answers to all the questions, presented in a way we’d understand. I get that the unknowable seems more alluring by nature of it being unknown. However, this isn’t who shot JFK (which is an important question) - this is the question of everything and it’s both intoxicating and frustrating.   Thank you very much for all your replies. You presented your thoughts in an easily digestible manner and clearly know a thing or two about a thing or two. I appreciate you and your time.
turn.5: Also, I can highly recommend the now very old “a brief history of time” by Stephen Hawking, if this sort of thing is interesting to you.
turn.6: I’ve wanted to read that for ages but was intimidated by it. Somehow I thought I’d never possibly understand what he was writing. Maybe I should finally check it out. Yet again, great tip.
turn.7: It’s intended “for the layman”, and if you’re asking these sorts of questions, you’re the audience he had in mind for it. I seem to remember it being much less dry than I had expected, and gave a glimpse into his sense of fun too. I’ve actually just re-ordered it after this conversation, as I lost my copy years ago. Must have lent it out at some point!  I can also really recommend “The man who mistook his wife for a hat” by Oliver Sacks - totally not physics related; but absolutely fascinating in a similar manner.
turn.8: I’m going to have to do the same. I used the have a respectable library. They seem to have mostly disappeared. Oliver Sacks is the doctor they based Awakenings on, right? I’d be interested in what he has to say.
turn.9: Yep, that’s the one. The book I mentioned is a series of his cases (anonymised) which give insights to how the brain seems to work based on how different injuries effect people.
turn.10: I think it’s fair to say my psyche has been injured from trying to understand this. It was so nice reading your replies. You were very helpful. Thank you very much.
turn.11: Thank you for a fun conversation :)
